comment_text: While I would love to see a United Ireland in the future I dont believe it would be as simplistic as removing the border and everything being run from Dublin……..

Or us wanting theirs. We can’t afford to take on the North at the moment, much as many of us would love the idea of a United Ireland. Plus, those Unionists would kick up ructions, and its probably not PC to say “Well lads if ye love Britain so much, there’s the boat”…

While I would love to see Irish reunification I don’t think that the time is right for a border poll. Once Brexit is triggered and the UK leaves the EU lets leave the Unionist community reap what they have sown. They overwhelmingly voted to leave the EU but they hadn’t thought the whole thing through. A huge amount of the PUL community gets it’s main income through subsides from the EU in the form of agri-grants and those are going to dry up along with all of the other EU grants for the Peace Process. Give it a few years for those to disappear and they will rethink their position.
At the same time people in the rest of the “mainland” and especially England will realise as to how much the Irish cost them each year. When I say Irish I say it because no matter how much Unionists insist that they are “British” they are actually perceived as “Irish” by the rest of the UK. They are after all not part of “mainland” UK. Why should someone in Kent or Essex pay for lunatic Paddy who likes to march up and down streets pissing off their neighbours and rioting all of the time?
It might take a while but sooner or later the rest of the UK will get tired of the Irish Question and find a way to cut NI loose. The EU will fall over itself to pour money in to this “new” country as a means to try to get a good PR vibe for “closer integration” i.e EU federalisation . the one thing that we would need is a political party that is on the side of Ireland and the Irish people whether it is an established party or a new one. It certainly wouldn’t be FG seeing as Flanagan reckons that we are on “Team EU” when it comes to Brexit rather than having Irish interests to the fore. Enda is happy that Merkel decides that Ireland is not a special case when it comes to Brexit even though as Enda declared a few years back that Ireland had to “take one for the team” in relation to austerity.
Do we really think that these Fine Gael clowns are interested in Ireland’s reunification when they are more interested in sucking up to their EU masters?

I live on the border these forty odd years and there is little advantage to anyone in having a united Ireland and introducing the problems of both states into one big melting pot. One only has to watch the NI news every day to see that the aftermath of the troubles remain in both catholic and Protestant neighbourhoods in a tit for tat way. Domestic violence is also prevelent in Northern Ireland as well as sectarian politics at Stormont.
In the republic we have learned to show mutual respect for our neighbours and no longer distinguish between catholics and protestants. The border is just a crossing point distinguished by different road signs. In the south we use euro and in the north it is sterling, but nobody worries about it as we now use credit cards on either side of the border. Cross border shopping is common and ofter better value can be found in the north on nearly everything from bread to s/h motor cars. NI towns tend to be cleaner with functional public toilets showing that local government in the north is better organised.
I don’t see any practical reason for a united Ireland until such times as both states can match each others standards.

May I suggest the following:
The division of Ireland (North & South) into 4 strong provincial State-like governments with a Central Secular Government whose powers are limited to Defence, Garda, Foreign Affairs, and National infrastructure etc with contentious issues such as education, welfare , health and local council matters left to the Provincial Governments.
Given that NI has some degree of political/economic autonomy already, the shift to a 4 provence All Ireland Government would not be a seismic shift politically or economically for them and a minor concession for Southerners. Let’s face it,
the 26 county Republic has not been a roaring success so far. Just ask any emigrant!
We can then get rid of Co Councils and replace them with community consultative committees with rotating honorary
reps.
Provincial Governments ought to have the powers to collect property taxes, stamp duties & levy garbage/environmental
charges (not water charges), the redistributing of VAT to the Provinces on a per capita basis and the balance of Central Government funds redistributed via a fair formula. We are already being dictated to by Brussels so why should have
this size of national Government who have to go cap in hand to the EC to have the budget passed.
This would give an opportunity to tailor government programs to better suit local needs and to get religion out of at least
Central Government Politics. At present the delivery of education & welfare is far too impersonal where the one shoe fits all is obviously not working.
The diaspora would dearly love to see a united Ireland where we all could, whether at home or abroad, call ourselves Irish and consign the “What Part” bit to history.

Sad to see the same patronising lies and half-truths have taken hold in Ireland. So much of the debate on Scotland’s economy fails to recognise the reasons for the apparent ‘deficit’, namely creative accounting (e.g. VAT appropriation), pejorative policy spanning decades and the vested interest of perhaps the ultimate manifestation of ‘the state’ in keeping the status quo.
The levers of UK economic control rest in London and as a resident of the affluent Home Counties I see where their effects are most apparent. All other areas of the UK – not just Scotland – suffer under this yoke. The money spent on a single London mega-infrastructure project (of which there are many) dwarves the funding for entire UK regions for years at a time.
However, instead of the debate being about balancing the country (empty ‘Northern Powerhouse’ rhetoric aside), the London Government is happy to watch regions play-off against one another. The ‘whinging Jocks’ with their grievances and their ‘grasping mitts held out for magnanimous handouts from a benevolent England’ trope has been well and truly set in the mind of many, even across the Irish Sea it would seem, where I would have thought detachment and history would have allowed a more cynical eye to fall across the scene.
Were Ireland still under Westminster rule it would be in exactly the same economic situation as Scotland is now, perhaps worse (see NI). Yet I doubt many would choose to return to a position of dependence.
Regardless of tired and, yes, pointless old economic flashpoints from 2014, the focus should very much be on two things:
1) The majority of the economic arguments against independence, spurious as some of them were, have been utterly dismantled in the light of Brexit. Think currency devaluation, leaving the Single Market etc. For many who advocated staying in the union because of potential economic downsides, watching Westminster rush headlong towards throwing the UK economy under a bus in the name of leaving the EU should be like a nuclear bomb going off, but it somehow isn’t because reasons, big red, white and blue reasons draped in closeted xenophobia. Bad for the goose is good for the gander?
But mainly:
2) The ultimate driver for independence is not some economic utopia just around the corner, but the very real and increasingly obvious democratic deficit in the UK. Self-determination is the overriding case for independence and the unfolding disaster of the parliamentary Brexit process only underlines how badly this is required.

Even some of the mouthpieces of the Irish capitalist class are beginning to call for an Irish exit from the E.U as continued membership of the union is now running increasingly contrary to capitalist class interests in the light of Brexit:
“I do not believe that Ireland signed up to join a European superstate with its own army and powers of taxation. Even if we had, we would have done so at a time when our closest neighbour, Britain, was part of the European project. Britain’s impending departure fundamentally changes Ireland’s balance of interest, as it faces remaining in an EU project that refuses to acknowledge any limit to its ambition.
The EU is now on a collision course with Irish national sovereignty………… Given the size of the economic threat posed to Ireland by Brexit and the scale of the political threat posed by the EU’s grandiose ambitions to overtly extend itself into areas where its activities have been largely covert until now — foreign affairs and tax — the lack of serious debate that has taken place about the country’s changing relationship with the EU is astonishing.

I seem to have listened to and read a different Theresa May than the one Dr Jordan did. Britain will leave the EU. It will introduce immigration controls, cease to contribute to the EU budget and no longer be subject to the EU law and courts.
It will seek access to the EU markets on terms. These terms may be WTO rules or perhaps an alternative along the lines of the TTIP proposals. What’s not clear?

@Ben Gunn: There is no clarity yet around:
The internal border on this island. What’s going to happen there exactly?
The period between when the UK leaves the economic block and a new deal can be negotiated. A ~10 year process? WTO rules mean that either side is entitled to levy any such tariffs as they wish, provided the average tariff level does not much exceed that of the other side. You think that can’t get messy, fast? What do you Johnson’s Prosecco comment a few months ago was about?
Financial Passporting. Not covered by WTO rules and London’s exposure is massive. Failure to agree here would hurt both sides a lot but it would crush the Pound and destroy London as a World Financial Capital.
Oil and Gas sales. Covered under WTO rules but offers a way for the EU to gain additional leverage by threatening to hurt Scotland disproportionately with Tariffs.
Oil and Gas Transmission. Not covered under WTO rules as what is being sold is the capacity to transfer gas and not the gas itself. The existing agreement (which includes Russia and the Middle East) would label the UK as an external Network. This will hammer us as our connection to that network is through Scotland.
Man, these WTO rules sure seem so stable and desirable. I wonder why some many countries like making additional trade deals then?

The UK based financial institutions will gain approval through their local offices. Tariff setting is always reciprocal. You tax my goods and I’ll tax yours. The parliamentary democracy system is the preferred form of rule for the capitalist class. It gives the majority working class the veneer of democracy while suppressing the possibility of any fundamental systemic change. This is typically achieved by having 2 parties with superficial differences but which both represent the capitalist ruling class. Tory Vs Labour in Britain, FF Vs FG in Ireland, Republicans Vs Democrats in the U.S. etc etc.
Big capital has always largely owned “democracy”. It’s a more resource efficient way of controlling the majority working class in comparison to brute force oppression. Democracy is not possible without an informed electorate and that is why the capitalist elite expend so much effort in keeping the majority misinformed as to the nature of the socio economic model which exploits them. The strategy is to control the information rather than direct control of the population by force which cannot be sustained indefinitely in any case.
So in other words, the election would result in an almost identical share of the vote as last time for all parties, which FF swapping places with FG as the minority govt.

49. In June 1995, Celia Larkin lodged £11,743.34 into Fianna Fail leader Bertie Ahern’s bank account. Ahern says that £10,000 sterling of this was actually his own money, part of £50,000 that he had earlier withdrawn from his own account and used to buy £30,000 sterling. However, the bank has no record of selling £30,000 sterling to anybody during that period.
50. In December 1994, Celia Larkin lodged IR£28,772.90 into Fianna Fail leader Bertie Ahern’s bank account. Ahern says that this was £30,000 sterling cash given to him in a briefcase by his soon-to-be landlord, just after he had become Fianna Fail leader and was expected to become Taoiseach However, the amount equates exactly to $45,000 based on bank exchange rates on that date.

Really? Lord Kerr, who wrote Article 50, told the BBC the following in November:
“It is not irrevocable. You can change your mind while the process is going on. They haven’t been “legally relegated to nothing more than suggestions.” They always were legally nothing more than public recommendations. Did you even watch the judgement? Leaving the EU means removing a whole section of UK law. The argument was that as a whole swathe of UK laws were being removed it necessitates an act of parliament. If being a member of the EU had had no impact on UK law, then the government itself, and not parliament as a whole, could have ratfied the results of the referendum. Today’s result was arrived at by precedence, followed the letter of the law, was fully democratic, and does not affect the result of the referendum. Referendums in Ireland operate on an entirely different legal and constitutional level.

Scotland’s deficit only matters because it’s denominated in a currency which they don’t issue. The same applies to Ireland.
Nations such as Britain which do issue a floating currency don’t face any budget constraint within that currency. They don’t need to tax or borrow in or order to finance government spending. The spend the currency into existence as they wish and the then tax it back out of circulation in a continuous flow.
For the state/currency issuer, money is simply a tool to measure and allocate real resources produced collectively by society through the labour of the working class.

@Mikhail Valtazar:
Brexit hasn’t happend yet. There’s only been a vote 6 months ago. Nothing else has happened, except their currency has nose-dived.

The depreciation of a currency is not necessarily a negative. As sterling depreciates this makes makes British exports much more competitive abroad and so they will tend to increase in volume which ultimately manifests as increased foreign currency reserves in the Bank of England.
IIn addition, imports are generally paid for in the currency of the importing nation and so the state can always afford to purchase anything for sale in the currency it issues regardless of the price.
In real terms, exports are a cost to a nation and imports are a benefit. A nation loses real resources (goods & services and the labour required to produce them) when it exports. In return it receives the currency of the nation it exported to. That currency is created by pressing computer keys or printing pieces of paper, nothing more. So the exporting nation has swapped it’s real wealth of goods and services for computer keystrokes or paper. The importing nation of course gets the benefit of the good & services it has purchased with electrons or paper.
The foreign currency which the exporting nation has received may in the future be used to purchase the products of the issuing nation (or converted to another currency) but there is no obligation on that nation to sell it’s goods & services if it chooses not to and it gets to decide at what price it will sell and for what currency.
“MMT emphasizes that in “real” terms, imports are a benefit and exports are a cost. Floating the currency and relaxing capital controls allows a nation to enjoy more “benefits” (imports) and fewer “costs” (exports). The nation can “afford” to enjoy all the output it can produce plus whatever output the rest of the world wants to sell to it. It “pays for” those net imports through expansion of its capital account surplus. On the capital account, this is reflected in rest of world accumulation of financial claims denominated in the importer’s currency.”
http://neweconomicperspectives.org/2014/02/mmt-external-constraints.html

This nonsense talk of an hard border between two parts of this island has got to stop. Look at Switzerland for an example. It is part of the Schengen Agreement and so are all the countries bordering it. As a result travellers generally do not have to show their passports but rather an official ID card. Moreover although private cars may be stopped on occasion for inspection, this is not always the case. Often frontier posts are not staffed at all and travellers are asked to fill in a customs declaration and leave it in a drop box. Passengers arriving at Swiss airports from non-Schengen countries must show their passports, Shengen arrivals do not.
There are plenty of ”fast lane” clearance procedures available to regular EU importers and exporters that can be availed of to reduce delays into and out of Ireland from UK provenance. Local import control, local export control, allow goods to speed through ports and land boundaries and subsequently be declared and duty paid by trusted traders. Everyone intending to do serious business with the UK and other third countries should consider applying for Authorised Economic Operator (AEO) status that will considerably simplify and expedite their customs obligations and processes.
Mutatis mutandis the same can be done for citizens of the Common Travel Area between IRL and UK as between Switzerland and the other Schengen Members. The EU will have no choice but to allow this, for otherwise it would be unfair and inequitable treatment of a member state vis a vis what other Member States can avail of. Stop all this scaremongering it’s bad for biz.
One thing we should copy from the Swiss is the ‘vignette’, or toll card, which non-Swiss cars must purchase entering Switzerland if they don’t already have one, and which covers the cost of road tolls for a year. That would stop Norns from using the M50 without paying tolls because there is no ANPR system here that can pick up Norn registration plates and allied names and addresses.

@John O’Driscoll: Switzerland permits free movement of people and upholds pretty much all EU law, so this arrangement is facilitated.
The UK doesn’t want to have anything to do with the EU, so the situation is much more complex and fraught.

@Garreth McDaid: read my comment again. I spoke only of free movement of common travel area citizens. The CTA long predates the ECSC, the EEC, the EC and EU, and is a legacy of our share 800 year history. Schengen incorporates EU and non-EU countries and citizens, so mutatis mutandis there is precedent for retaining the CTA. Switzerland is not in the Customs Union, and operates a semi-open border using modern WTO / WCO concepts, such as AYUSCUDA etc. No reason the same sit can’t pertain here and UK.

As part of Brexit the EU should be funding development of links between Ireland and mainland Europe. We need a way to bypass Britain or they can add charges on all or exports traveling through.

There’s a potentially serious issue underlying this.
A huge proportion of Irish exports to the European Mainland cross the UK. If there are tariffs post-Brexit, it is going to become a complete pain in the backside for our goods to leave the EU and re-enter.
Unless we can find some way of agreeing that transshipped goods can be sealed prior to leaving Ireland and only reopened afterwards, we are going to need to look seriously at getting Irish Ferries and Brittany Ferries to increase commercial capacity to France.

@Chris Mansfield:
If the UK does leave the customs union and there will be tariffs, then the EU will simply have to fund the development of a direct route for us. If not we need to pay for it ourselves as a national economic emergency.

@Fred Johnson: I would be interested to know how much infrastructure we actually need to build.
For one thing, the Ro-Ro berth in Cork is only used once a week by Brittany Ferries since Fastnet Lines went out of business. That could go up to two or three a day (although it would require the M28 plan to be fast-tracked).
You’d also have to assume that some freight would be diverted, leading to reductions in UK routes. Could Rosslare sustain 4 services a day to Fishguard/Pembroke. Could the capacity there be redirected to French routes.
Much of the trouble is that the routes are operated by commercial operators and they may need some form of incentives to increase capacity.

@Turlough Conway:
That court case is not vital at all. The UK parliament will vote through A50, and I’ll tell you why.
Let’s imagine for a moment that UK parliament blocked A50. This would almost certainly trigger a ‘snap’ General election in the UK (the recent fixed term Parliament laws still allow for elections in exceptional circumstances). All current polling puts May miles ahead of Labour and the smaller parties. The election would become a ballot on brexit. With Theresa Mays Conservative committed to delivering Brexit and all the other parties (except Ukip) fighting the election on a remain platform, what do you think would happen? The conservative party currently holds a majority in the UK parliament that was won with a lot less than 17 million votes (circa 10mil I think it was – I stand to be corrected!). Even if some of those who voted for Brexit changed their minds, there would still be only one outcome, a massive win for the Conservative party and a huge new majority in the houses of parliament. Many potential conservative candidates in such an election will be faced with the choice of fighting the campaign on a Brexit footing or losing their seat to Ukip, who could obviously stand to gain from such an election, but would of course offer no hindrance to the passage of the A50 bill through parliament.
All the incumbent MPs know this, that is why Labour will not block the A50 bill. They don’t want a conservative party that sits on a 400 seat majority any more than anyone else does, despite the obvious opportunity it would give them to finally get rid of Jeremy Corbyn.

Absolutely no surprises in this speech although a lot of it is still more aspirational than realisable:
1) Both very desirable and very possible but will require overall agreement of how to manage the passage of people from the island of Ireland to mainland UK, including non-Irish EU nationals. Most likely a soft border with the North and a harder border with the mainland, enforced at Ferry ports and Airports.
2) A “TTIP-style” trade agreement between the EU and Europe is the work of a decade. In order for this to be achieved seamlessly there would need to be a transition period of at least 5 years to wind the UK out of the common market and move them into this new agreement. May has said that won’t happen so Irish vendors with strong links should, at the least, be preparing for short term tariffs. It seems from her posture that May would like these to be set at a non-punitive level for a period of time as a preference to a transition period. This will be a hard sell for some EU countries who just won’t benefit from it.
4) I’d be amazed is Scotland is still part of the UK in a decade but ultimately that is a Scotland-England issue. I bring it up only because the tone set here will not fly in Holyrood *unless* May can get them serious concessions on the transfer and sale of their North Sea Gas. The current EU wide agreement here would put Scotland squarely in the Russia box (ie 3rd Party Transporter) which will mean high tariffs for using the European transmission network. This would be very bad for Ireland as we’d get hammered for Gas moving in to Scotland and again to get it back across our inter-connectors. This is one of the areas where our government really needs to be on the ball. Shame they haven’t even mentioned it yet…..
6) Pretty sure the Americans won’t be allowing the Brits to share their intelligence with the EU, there is already a different, more restricted agreement in place that. I reckon this is just being thrown out as a disingenuous platitude. At the very least the UK won’t be sacrificing it’s security for that of it’s neighbours anymore, that’s a huge reason why this is happening in the first place.

Both Adams and Farage are right for once. For the first 400 years following Henry ll’s invasion in 1169 the pope was sovereign of Ireland- Henry was subordinate to the pontiff and designated as Lord of Ireland. There wasn’t much opposition to this arrangement from the Irish. It was only when Henry VIII converted to the Protestant faith, removed the title of sovereign from the pope and took it for himself, that the Irish began to rebel against foreign occupation. For the next 400 years the Church did all it could to regain the control it once enjoyed. Following independence the Church’s influence was re-established and actually enshrined in the 1937 constitution. This subservient attitude permeated all levels of Irish society, with one ex IRA chief of staff- the so called radical Sean MacBride- telling the pope in 1948: “my colleagues and myself desire to repose at the feet of Your Holiness the assurance of our filial loyalty and devotion…”. So, yes, Irish nationalism has always been selective in its objection to foreign interference

If you think Irish history was a history of religious obedience you misunderstand it

@Turlough Conway: I think describing the Church’s position as “pro British” after emancipation is stretching it a little. They were more acquiescent having gained a significant reform, but not pro British. As for the Rising- nearly everyone opposed it. As for the War of Independence- less than half the electorate voted for the only independence party- Sinn Fein- so it’s debatable just how many agreed with the Dáil’s ratification of what was essentially a killing campaign against the RIC, and no surprise then that the Church opposed it. It may well have opposed the means but the Church wanted an independent Ireland in order to strengthen its own position. If it’s untrue that “Irish history was a history of religious obedience”, give me some examples of dissent.

“Afternoon, Sir. Can we help?”
“Yeah – I want a better deal on my membership.”
“OK, here’s the best we can do.”
“That’s not good enough for me.”
“Really? No-one else in the club has such a deal.”
“Well, I don’t like the paying and I don’t like the rules. I don’t like how we vote. You’re all a dictator. I’ve decided – I’m leaving. I’m cancelling my membership.”
“OK”
“But I still want access.”
“Right. OK – we can sort out some partial access deal… but you’d need full membership for full access.”
“Oh, so you want to punish me for not being a member, eh?!”
“No…”
“Yes, you’re punishing me. You’re just like a WWII prison guard beating me for trying to escape.”
“Um, what? You’re free to go…”
“You need me more than I need you!”
“Please go…”

“The Article 50 withdrawal procedure is fundamentally flawed, mainly against the departing state.”
In my view this statement misunderstands the Article 50 withdrawal procedure. Yes, the process is loaded against the departing state and places them at a significant disadvantage. That much is true. But this isn’t a flaw in the process. It’s an integral part of it.
An organisation like the EU lives or dies by internal stability. Any activity damaging to that stability (i.e. the withdrawal of a member state) must be actively discouraged. This isn’t some underhand European conspiracy… it’s the nature of almost all large organisations to resist and disincentivise disturbance and uncertainty.
While we in Ireland may want a “soft Brexit”, and while European negotiators will publicly speak about “securing the best deal for everyone”, in reality if Britain is not negatively impacted by the Article 50 procedure, then it won’t have done what it was designed to do… discourage nations from choosing it.

Here is the text to the conclusions to a Civitas report about the spike Ruairi mentions. It pretty much debunks it.
“There was a rise in reported hate crime incidents in the immediate aftermath of the EU
referendum. Precisely what this signified, however, is open to question.
First, it should be noted that the vast majority of recorded hate crime incidents consist of verbal harassment
rather than physical violence. Further to that, the police definition of a hate crime is one that
is „perceived‟ by the victim to have been based on prejudice; this means that in the strictest
sense the surge in reported incidents only represents a surge in perceived prejudice. This is
an important caveat usually ignored in media coverage. Many crimes reported as being hate
crimes, most notably including specific incidents that have been highlighted by the media in
recent weeks, actually have little evidence to support them being classified as such. By the
same token, there is usually little if anything to connect individual incidents with the EU
referendum, even if there have been many more people reporting „hate crimes‟ since the
vote.
It should also be noted that reported hate crime has been trending upwards for the last few
years, long before the EU referendum campaign began.
Does this reflect a widespread increase in intolerance towards certain minorities? Or does it reflect the rising profile of hate crime as a category of offence and the opportunity to report it via, for example, True Vision?
It is difficult to say with any certainty but there is no objective barometer signalling rising
intolerance. Similarly with the surge in reports in the aftermath of the referendum. It seems
as likely that reports of hate crime were being fuelled by the perception of a rise of
intolerance, which was in turn fuelled by police and media reports driven by that perception,
in a vicious circle. “
